metadata.description: Ingredient interaction guidelines for skincare formulations

compatibility_rules.explanation: Can be used together with proper formulation or separated by time. Use Vitamin C (morning) and Retinol (night) for optimal results without irritation.
Both are powerful exfoliants. Alternate nights recommended: Retinol Mon/Wed/Fri, AHA Tue/Thu. Can layer after skin tolerance builds (8-12 weeks).
Similar to AHA, both exfoliate. Start with alternating nights. Advanced users may combine after tolerance is established.
Excellent combination. Apply HA to damp skin first for hydration, then Retinol. HA buffers Retinol irritation.
Tretinoin is prescription-strength. Adding AHA causes severe irritation and barrier damage. Use Tretinoin alone or consult dermatologist.
Same as Tretinoin + AHA. Prescription Tretinoin is sufficient exfoliation. Adding BHA causes excessive irritation.
Old myth debunked. They work synergistically for brightening. The conversion to Niacin (flushing) only occurs at extreme temperatures, not on skin.
Copper peptides oxidize and destabilize Vitamin C. Use Vitamin C (AM) and Copper Peptides (PM) or alternate days.
Benzoyl Peroxide is an oxidizing agent that degrades Vitamin C completely. Use BP (night) for acne, Vitamin C (morning) for antioxidants.
Both can cause dryness. Use separately: BP (morning) or spot treatment, Retinol (night). May deactivate each other.
Can be combined for acne + hyperpigmentation. Start alternating nights, then layer after 2-3 weeks if tolerated (BHA first, then Azelaic).
Excellent combination for rosacea, pigmentation, and acne. Both gentle and complementary.
Work well together for oily/acne-prone skin. Niacinamide regulates sebum; BHA unclogs pores.
Compatible. AHA exfoliates; Niacinamide strengthens barrier. Apply AHA first, then Niacinamide.
Can be layered for comprehensive exfoliation (BHA for pores, AHA for surface). Start alternating if sensitive. Many products combine both.
Both are acidic (low pH). Can cause irritation together. Use Vitamin C (AM), AHA (PM) for safety.
Synergistic antioxidants. Ferulic Acid stabilizes Vitamin C and boosts efficacy. Often formulated together (e.g., SkinCeuticals C E Ferulic).
Compatible. Peptides support collagen synthesis; Retinol increases cell turnover. Layer peptides first (lighter), then Retinol.
Ideal combination. Ceramides repair barrier damage caused by Retinol. Apply Retinol, then ceramide-rich moisturizer.
Perfect hydration + barrier repair combo. HA attracts water; ceramides seal it in. Apply HA to damp skin, then ceramides.

timing_definitions.same_routine: Can be applied in the same AM or PM routine, typically layered one after another
timing_definitions.separate_am_pm: Use one ingredient in AM routine, the other in PM routine
timing_definitions.alternate_nights: Use on different nights (e.g., Ingredient A on Mon/Wed/Fri, Ingredient B on Tue/Thu/Sat)
timing_definitions.alternate_or_layer: Start by alternating; advanced users can layer after building tolerance
timing_definitions.avoid_combination: Do not use together; choose one or consult professional

general_guidelines: Always introduce one active ingredient at a time (4-6 week intervals)
Start with lower concentrations and build up tolerance
Apply actives on clean, dry skin unless product specifies otherwise
Layer from thinnest to thickest consistency (serum → cream → oil)
Apply water-based products before oil-based products
Wait 1-2 minutes between active ingredient applications
Always use broad-spectrum SPF 30+ during daytime when using active ingredients
If irritation occurs, reduce frequency or concentration
Patch test new combinations on jawline for 24-48 hours
Consult dermatologist before combining prescription actives (Tretinoin, Hydroquinone, etc.)

special_considerations.sensitive_skin: Limit to 1-2 actives maximum. Prioritize barrier repair (ceramides, centella).
special_considerations.dry_skin: Use hydrating layers (HA, glycerin) between actives. Avoid over-exfoliation.
special_considerations.oily_acne_prone: Can tolerate more actives. Focus on BHA, Niacinamide, Benzoyl Peroxide combinations.
special_considerations.mature_skin: Retinoids + antioxidants (Vitamin C, E, Ferulic) + peptides are key. Build slowly.
special_considerations.rosacea: Avoid all acids during flares. Azelaic Acid + Niacinamide are safest actives.
